credentials.label: Credentials & Setup
credentials.comment:
Documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/
Indexing troubleshooting guide: https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/getting_started/quick_start.html
FAQ: https://docs.meilisearch.com/faq.html
Issues: https://github.com/meilisearch/meilisearch/issues

status.label: MeiliSearch Status
status.comment: Real-time connection status and statistics from your MeiliSearch server

enable_backend.label: Enable Indexing
enable_backend.comment: If set to No, Meilisearch extension will not index your data automatically.

enable_frontend.label: Enable Search
enable_frontend.comment: If set to No, search will be done by Magento but indexing will be done by Meilisearch

debug.label: Enable Logging
debug.comment:
⚠ Warning: Debug logging generates significant data and can slow indexing performance.
üí° Use only for troubleshooting and disable in production.

server_url.label: Meilisearch Server URL
server_url.comment:
Your Meilisearch server URL (e.g., http://localhost:7700 or https://your-meilisearch-instance.com)
üí° Tip: For local development, use http://localhost:7700. For production, use HTTPS for security.

search_results_url.label: Custom Search Results URL
search_results_url.comment:
Custom URL endpoint for search requests (default: /meilisearch). This URL should match your proxy configuration.

üìñ Nginx Proxy Configuration
location /meilisearch {
    proxy_pass http://localhost:7700;
    proxy_http_version 1.1;
    proxy_set_header Host $host;
    proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
    proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
}
üìñ Apache Proxy Configuration
# Enable proxy modules
# a2enmod proxy proxy_http

ProxyPass /meilisearch http://localhost:7700
ProxyPassReverse /meilisearch http://localhost:7700

<Location /meilisearch>
    ProxyPreserveHost On
    RequestHeader set X-Real-IP %{REMOTE_ADDR}s
    RequestHeader set X-Forwarded-For %{REMOTE_ADDR}s
    RequestHeader set X-Forwarded-Proto https
</Location>

api_key.label: Master Key
api_key.comment:
Your Meilisearch master key (kept private)
‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Keep this key secure! It has full access to all indexes.
Learn about API keys

search_only_api_key.label: Search API Key (optional)
search_only_api_key.comment:
A search-only API key for frontend use (optional - if not set, master key will be used)
üîí Security: It's highly recommended to use a search-only key for frontend to prevent unauthorized write access.
Learn about tenant tokens

index_prefix.label: Index Name Prefix
index_prefix.comment:
If configured, all indices created by the Meilisearch search extension will be prefixed by this value.
Default: maho_
üí° Tip: Use prefixes to separate environments (e.g., dev_, staging_, prod_) or multiple stores on same MeiliSearch instance

is_popup_enabled.label: Enable Auto-completion Menu
is_popup_enabled.comment: If set to Yes, the search box will display a search-as-you-type drop-down menu. It requires your theme to expose a top.search and content block.

is_instant_enabled.label: Enable Instant Search Results Page
is_instant_enabled.comment:
If set to Yes, the products inside the results pages will be searchable the refined results updated as-you-type. It requires your theme to expose a top.search and content block.

⚠ Enabling instant search can potentially break your design, some work will be required to have a good integration into your theme products.

use_adaptive_image.label: Replace default image by matching variation
use_adaptive_image.comment:
E.g. When a customer searches for a "blue dress", Meilisearch will display the image associated with the blue variation instead of the default picture. The same happens when a customer refines products by any color.

If a customer searches for "blue dress" and refines by "red" color, Meilisearch will display images for red (refined) color.

autocomplete.label: Autocomplete
autocomplete.comment: To customize autocomplete menu beyond its configuration, you can read tutorials: To customize autocomplete menu beyond its configuration, please refer to the Meilisearch documentation

nb_of_products_suggestions.label: Number of products
nb_of_products_suggestions.comment:
The number of products (0 to disable it) suggested in the autocomplete dropdown.
Default: 6
üí° Recommendation: 4-8 products for optimal UX without overwhelming users

nb_of_categories_suggestions.label: Number of categories
nb_of_categories_suggestions.comment:
The number of categories (0 to disable it) suggested in the autocomplete dropdown.
Default: 2
üí° Recommendation: 2-3 categories to guide users without clutter

nb_of_queries_suggestions.label: Number of queries
nb_of_queries_suggestions.comment: The number of queries suggestions (0 to disabled it) suggested in the autocomplete dropdown. Default value is 0.

min_popularity.label: Min query popularity
min_popularity.comment:
The min number of times a query has been performed in order to be suggested.
Default: 1000
üí° Tip: Lower this value (e.g., 100-500) for new stores to show suggestions sooner

min_number_of_results.label: Min number of products per query
min_number_of_results.comment: The min number of results a query needs to return to be suggested. Default value is 2. <br /n>

display_categories_with_suggestions.label: Display categories with suggestions?
display_categories_with_suggestions.comment:
If set to Yes, suggestion will be displayed like:
- Suggestion in All departments
- Suggestion in [most popular category
- Suggestion

If set to No, suggestions will be displayed without "All departments" and most popular category.

sections.label: Additional Sections
sections.comment:
Configure here the additional auto-completion menu sections you want include in the dropdown menu (Ex. Suggestions, Pages, Manufacturer, Colors).

⚠ All attributes used here must have been initially included in the Attributes Configuration panel and configured as a facet in the Instant Search Results Page Configuration panel to be able to refine on the specific attribute.

excluded_pages.label: Excluded Pages
excluded_pages.comment:
Configure here the pages you don't want to search in.
Pages' indexing documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/core_concepts/indexes.html

render_template_directives.label: Render template directives
render_template_directives.comment:
For CMS pages, template directives (e.g. {{block type="core/template" ...}}) will be processed by default. Set this to "No" if you don't want to have template content indexed.

⚠ Do not forget to trigger the Meilisearch Search indexers whenever you modify those settings.

debug.label: Enable autocomplete menu's debug mode
debug.comment: When set to Yes, autocomplete menu won't disappear when clicked outside of the menu. It's useful when you debug / style the look of autocomplete menu.

instant.label: Instant Search Results Page
instant.comment: To customize instant search results page beyond its configuration, you can read tutorials: To customize instant search results page beyond its configuration, please refer to the Meilisearch documentation

instant_selector.label: DOM Selector
instant_selector.comment: The DOM selector used to inject the results using JavaScript.

facets.label: Facets
facets.comment:
Configure here the filtering options you want to display on your search results page. Choose Disjunctive to allow the selection of different values of a facet (e.g. hotels with 4 OR 5 stars). Choose Conjunctive to allow the selection of only one value of a facet (e.g. only "Size M").
Set facet as searchable if you want your customers to be able to search for facet values. It's handy when a facet has a lot of values.
Facets' documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/getting_started/filtering_and_sorting.html

Create a Query rule for facet when you want Meilisearch to automatically filter on a facet when a user searches for its value in query. It means when you create a Query rule for "color" facet and user is searching for query "red shorts", Meilisearch will internally filter results for color "red" and search only for query "shorts". It leads to more relevant users. This query rule is applied for both autocomplete and instant search results. Query rules can be used only when you are on Business or higher plan.

max_values_per_facet.label: Number of values per facet
max_values_per_facet.comment:
The number of values each facet can display.
Default: 10
üí° Tip: 5-10 values work best. Use searchable facets for attributes with many values (e.g., brands, colors)

sorts.label: Sorts
sorts.comment:
Configure here the different sorting options you want to offer.
Sorts documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/getting_started/filtering_and_sorting.html#sorting

The extension will create :
- 1 index/store
- 1 index/store/sort

Which means that for a store with:
- 2 store (2 languages for example)
- 100 products
- 2 sorts on price (asc, desc)
- 2 sorts on date (asc, desc)

You have 100 * 2 + 100 * 4 * 2 = 1000 product records You can reduce the number of records by removing some sort

replace_categories.label: Replace categories page
replace_categories.comment: Choose here if you want the default Magento category pages to be replaced by an instant-search results page when a category is selected either in the menu of categories or in the drop-down menu.

add_to_cart_enable.label: Add to Cart
add_to_cart_enable.comment: Choose here if you want to add an "add to cart" button in the template.

infinite_scroll_enable.label: Enable Infinite Scroll
infinite_scroll_enable.comment: This will display a show more button to load more results instead of traditional pagination.

number_product_results.label: Number of products per page in the instant result page
number_product_results.comment:
The number of products displayed on the instant search results page.
Default: 9
üí° Recommendation: Use multiples of 3 or 4 for better grid layouts (e.g., 12, 16, 20)

product_additional_attributes.label: Attributes
product_additional_attributes.comment:
Choose here the product attributes your users can search on, the ones you want to use as filters and sorts options and the ones required to display the search results.
Searchable attributes' documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/reference/api/settings.html#searchable-attributes

The order of the searchable attributes matters: a query matching the first searchable attribute of a product will put this product before the others in the results. Chose "Ordered" if you want the position of the matching word(s) inside the attribute to matter. A match at the beginning of an attribute will be considered more important: for the query "iPhone", "iPhone 5s" will be ranked before "case for iPhone".

Index empty value means that if a product attribute isn't set the default value (probably No or N/A, depends on your translations) will not be indexed. This can be handy for categories where not all products do have all attributes set which can cause a lot of "No" facet values.

⚠ Do not forget to reindex your Meilisearch Search index after you've modified this panel.

custom_ranking_product_attributes.label: Ranking
custom_ranking_product_attributes.comment:
Configure here the attributes that reflect the popularity of your product (number of orders, number of likes, number of views, ...).
What is Custom ranking? https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/core_concepts/relevancy.html#ranking-rules

In case you want to use attribute which cannot be selected from the select box (eg. attribute indexed from outside of Magento), you can use "[use custom attribute]" option and write the name of the attribute into the new text field.

⚠ All attributes used here must have been initially included in the Attributes configuration panel.

ranking_rules.label: Ranking Rules Order
ranking_rules.comment:
Define the order of ranking rules (one per line). Default MeiliSearch rules:
words
typo
proximity
attribute
sort
exactness

Custom ranking attributes will be added automatically after these rules.
Learn more: MeiliSearch Ranking Rules

show_suggestions_on_no_result_page.label: Show most popular queries suggestions when there are no results
show_suggestions_on_no_result_page.comment: Choose here if you want to show most popular queries suggestions when there are no results

index_visibility.label: Index products with visibility:
index_visibility.comment:
Choose which products you want to index (search for) in Meilisearch.
⚠ If you select "Only products visible in Search" and you have enabled "Replace categories pages", you might miss some products on category pages.

index_out_of_stock_options.label: Index out of stock options for configurable products
index_out_of_stock_options.comment: Choose here if you want to index out of stock options for configurable products

index_whole_category_tree.label: Index whole category tree of product
index_whole_category_tree.comment:
Choose here if you want to index whole category tree of the product. If you select "No", only real categories of the product will be indexed.

For example if you have categories with structure "Men » Blazers" and product belongs only to "Blazers", by default categories "Men" and "Men » Blazers" will be indexed. By selecting "No" only "Men » Blazers" will be indexed.

⚠ Beware that selecting "No" will break hierarchical menu widget on instant search page.

category_additional_attributes2.label: Attributes
category_additional_attributes2.comment:
Configure here the category attributes your users can search on. The order of these attributes matters: the higher in the list, the more important to rank the results.
Searchable attributes' documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/reference/api/settings.html#searchable-attributes

⚠ Do not forget to reindex your Meilisearch Search index after you've modified this panel.

custom_ranking_category_attributes.label: Ranking
custom_ranking_category_attributes.comment:
Choose here the attributes that reflect the popularity of your categories (number of products, total number of sales of the category,etc.).
What is Custom ranking? https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/core_concepts/relevancy.html#ranking-rules

In case you want to use attribute which cannot be selected from the select box (eg. attribute indexed from outside of Magento), you can use "[use custom attribute]" option and write the name of the attribute into the new text field.

⚠ All attributes used here must have been included before in the Attributes chart.

show_cats_not_included_in_navigation.label: Show categories that are not included in the navigation menu
show_cats_not_included_in_navigation.comment: If set to Yes, Meilisearch will display all categories in both the autocomplete menu and instant search page ignoring the setting: "Include in navigation menu". Default value: No

index_empty_categories.label: Index empty categories?
index_empty_categories.comment: If set to Yes, Meilisearch will display all categories in both the autocomplete menu and instant search page ignoring if they contain products or not. Default value: No

image.label: Images
image.comment: If you have issues with images: If images are not showing up, check image paths and permissions

height.label: Height
height.comment:
You can specify the size of the images used at the Search Results Page.
If your images are already present in some size, e.g. 265x265, Meilisearch's index job may not have to resize those, potentially saving time and resources.

type.label: Type
type.comment: The image used at the Search Results Page.

queue.label: Indexing Queue / Cron
queue.comment:
Indexing queue documentation: Queue indexing allows for asynchronous index updates to improve performance
Indexing troubleshooting guide: https://docs.meilisearch.com/learn/getting_started/quick_start.html

number_of_element_by_page.label: Max number of element per indexing job
number_of_element_by_page.comment:
The max number of elements per indexing job.
Default: 100
üí° Performance Tip:
‚Ä¢ Small catalogs (< 10k products): 100-500
‚Ä¢ Medium catalogs (10k-50k): 200-300
‚Ä¢ Large catalogs (> 50k): 100-200
Lower values = more stable, higher values = faster indexing

active.label: Queue Enabled
active.comment:
If enabled, all indexing operations (add, remove & update operations) will be done asynchronously using the CRON mechanism.

To schedule the run you need to add this in your crontab:
*/5 * * * * php -f /absolute/path/to/magento/shell/indexer.php -- -reindex meilisearch_queue_runner

⚠ Enabling this option is recommended in production or if your store has a lot of products.

number_of_job_to_run.label: Number of jobs to run each time the cron is run
number_of_job_to_run.comment:
Number of jobs to run each time the cron is run.
Default: 10
üìä Example calculation:
With defaults: 100 elements √ó 10 jobs = 1,000 products per cron run

⚠ Each cron run processes: (Elements per job √ó Number of jobs) products
üí° Tip: Adjust based on your cron frequency and catalog size

number_of_retries.label: Number of times to retry processing of queued jobs
number_of_retries.comment: Select the number of times to retry events that have failed the indexes check.

check_price_index.label: Should check if the prices were reindexed before pushing to Meilisearch?
check_price_index.comment:
Use only when on Enterprise Edition with enabled asynchronous price reindexing.
If set to Yes, the queue checks if all the products which are supposed to be indexed in Meilisearch has reindexed prices. If they don't those products will be skipped and pushed to Meilisearch when they have its' prices reindexed.

check_stock_index.label: Should check if the stock was reindexed before pushing to Meilisearch?
check_stock_index.comment:
Use only when on Enterprise Edition with enabled asynchronous price reindexing.
If set to Yes, the queue checks if all the products which are supposed to be indexed in Meilisearch has reindexed stock. If they don't those products will be skipped and pushed to Meilisearch when they have its' stock reindexed.

analytics.label: Google Analytics
analytics.comment: Google Analytics documentation: Analytics helps you understand search behavior on your site

delay.label: Delay (in milliseconds)
delay.comment:
When the search bar is used, each keystroke triggers a search in Meilisearch. It‚Äôs really good for an instantsearch and as-you-type search UX, but it‚Äôs not that good for analytics as it generates a lot of data and brings a lot of noise to the analytics. The delay variable defines how long the widget should wait between keystrokes before pushing data to analytics - only the last search will be pushed.

Default value: 3000

trigger_on_ui_interaction.label: Trigger the push function before the the delay on UI interaction
trigger_on_ui_interaction.comment:
If the user selects a search result even before the push was trigger (because of the delay variable), the push to analytics might never be called. With this parameter you can trigger a data push to analytics if the user interacts with the search results during the delay.

Default value: Yes

push_initial_search.label: Trigger the push function after the initial search
push_initial_search.comment:
Sometimes your customers come directly to the search page from a link, so a search is triggered automatically without any action from the user. At the same time, the load of the page triggers standard Google Analytics code to track the page view. By this parameter you can specify if you want to trigger a data push on this kind of search scenario.

Default value: No

enable_synonyms.label: Enable Synonyms management
enable_synonyms.comment: If set to No, synonyms will be managed only in Meilisearch's dashboard and won't get overriden by Magento

synonyms.label: Synonyms
synonyms.comment:
Synonyms are defined by a comma-separated list of words that should be considered equivalent by the Meilisearch engine.
For instance: tv, television, tv set
Using that set, if a record contains ‚Äútelevision‚Äù and a user searches for ‚ÄúTV‚Äù, this record will be returned.
Documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/reference/api/settings.html#synonyms

oneway_synonyms.label: One-way Synonyms
oneway_synonyms.comment:
One-way synonyms allow you to define alternative words for a search term, which are not synonyms to each others.
Let‚Äôs take an example: when a user searches for ‚Äútablet‚Äù, you want him to be able to find iPads and Galaxy Note tablets alike, but you might not want Android tablets to show up when he searches for ‚ÄúiPad‚Äù.
To do this, you‚Äôd define a one-way synonyms set between tablet (as input) and ipad, galaxy note (as synonyms). When the user types in ‚Äútablet‚Äù, records containing ‚ÄúiPad‚Äù and ‚ÄúGalaxy Note‚Äù will be returned. However records containing only ‚Äútablet‚Äù or ‚ÄúGalaxy Note‚Äù won‚Äôt be returned if he searches for ‚ÄúiPad‚Äù.
Documentation: https://docs.meilisearch.com/reference/api/settings.html#synonyms

Meilisearch offers more synonymys‚Äô types - placeholders and alternative corrections. These types can be managed directly from your Meilisearch‚Äôs dashboard. Any changes you will make to placeholders and alternative corrections in Meilisearch‚Äôs dashboard won‚Äôt be overriden.

synonyms_file.label: Synonyms File
synonyms_file.comment:
If you have large amount of synonyms (appr. more than hundred), you don't have to fill it into inputs above and you can upload a JSON file with synonyms instead. The documentation with the file structure can be found here.

⚠ When you upload a JSON file, all the synonyms settings from above will be ignored and only synonyms from the JSON file will be pushed to Meilisearch.

remove_words_if_no_result.label: Remove Words If No Result?
remove_words_if_no_result.comment:
Optional property to avoid empty result pages.
By default, Meilisearch performs "AND" queries, which can lead to no results pages when queries are too long or too detailed. To avoid this, you can select among the following options:
LastWords: when a query does not return any result, the last word will be considered as optional and the query will be automatically performed again (the process is repeated with the n-1 word, n-2 word, ... until there is results).
FirstWords: when a query does not return any result, the first word will be considered as optional and the query will be automatically performed again (the process is repeated with the second word, third word, ... until there is results).
allOptional: when a query does not return any result, all words will be optional.
None: No specific processing is done when a query does not return any result.

partial_update.label: Partial Updates
partial_update.comment: If enabled, all add/update operations will use partialUpdateObjects instead of addObjects. You should enable this option if you update some attributes of your records from an external source in addition to Magento to avoid any overriding.

customer_groups_enable.label: Customer Groups
customer_groups_enable.comment:
If enabled, the extension will take into account your customer groups and display the price of the logged-in group instead of the default price.
Enabling this option creates an index per customer group.

make_seo_request.label: Make SEO request
make_seo_request.comment: Choose if a query to Meilisearch is done by the backend for SEO when instant search is enabled

remove_branding.label: Remove branding logo
remove_branding.comment: Choose here if the meilisearch logo is added to the drop-down template.

show_queue_notification.label: Show queue information panel in administration header

autocomplete_selector.label: Search input DOM Selector
autocomplete_selector.comment: If you don't have the top.search block you can specify the selector of your search input here to use it. Default value is .meilisearch-search-input

index_product_on_category_products_updat.label: Update product on category products update
index_product_on_category_products_updat.comment:
This feature enables the extension to automatically update the product index when a product is added to or removed from a category via the "Manage Categories" menu. By default the feature is turned on.
Setting it to "No" will disable its behavior. It is useful when you hava a lot of products in catalog and saving the category will synchronize them all with Meilisearch even though there is no real change.

index_all_category_product_on_category_u.label: Update all category products on category update
index_all_category_product_on_category_u.comment:
This feature enables the extension to automatically update the product index when category is updated. By default the feature is turned off.
This feature should not be enabled all the time as it generates large amount of operations. It should be enabled only when category is renamed / moved / etc... and its products need to be reindexed.

prevent_backend_rendering.label: Prevent backend rendering?
prevent_backend_rendering.comment: ⚠ By preventing your store from backend rendering you might break your SEO and accessibility of your store by search crawlers. Please, read documentation before you turn the backend rendering off: Prevent Backend Rendering can improve SEO and performance

backend_rendering_allowed_user_agents.label: Allow backend rendering for User Agents:
backend_rendering_allowed_user_agents.comment: To specify multiple User-Agents, please put one User-Agent per line.

non_castable_attributes.label: Product numeric textfield attributes
non_castable_attributes.comment: Choose here the textfield attributes that you don't want to be turned into numeric values (i.e. : if you don't want "00123" turned into "123")

advanced_settings.label: Advanced - Extra Meilisearch indices settings
advanced_settings.comment:
Here, you can specify additional Meilisearch indices settings which can be applied only programatically via one of Meilisearch API clients.

To set an extra settings, please fill the right textarea with JSON where you specify the extra settings.
Example: {"exactOnSingleWordQuery":"word"}

List of possible settings: https://docs.meilisearch.com/reference/api/settings.html

⚠ Edit extra settings only when you're sure what you're doing. Bad settings can effect your search functionality and have a bad impact on your relevance.
